title: 108_s168
content: The Act is titled the "San Francisco Old Mint Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. The San Francisco Old Mint played a crucial role in the nation's history by converting miners' gold into coins. Designed by architect A.B. Mullett, it survived the 1906 earthquake and fire, serving as the only operational financial institution and treasury for disaster relief funds in San Francisco. Coins minted there are distinguished by the "S" Mint Mark. The San Francisco Old Mint, known for its rare coins like the 1870-S $3 coin valued over $1,000,000, will have the first commemorative coin to honor a mint. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins in commemoration of the San Francisco Old Mint. The $5 coins will weigh 8.359 grams, have a diameter of .850 inches, and contain 90% gold. The $1 coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. All coins minted under this Act will be considered numismatic items under section 5134 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary can obtain gold and silver from any available source for minting coins under this Act. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the San Francisco Old Mint Building, its significance to California and US history, and its role in rebuilding San Francisco after the 1906 earthquake and fire. Each coin will include the coin's value, the year "2006", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design for the coins will be selected accordingly. The design for the coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts, the Board of the San Francisco Museum and Historical Society, the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee, and the Board of the San Francisco Museum and Historical Society. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from January 1, 2006, to December 31, 2006, at the San Francisco Mint. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. The Secretary will distribute surcharges from coin sales to the San Francisco Museum and Historical Society, subject to audit requirements.
